newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Murderer urges poison biscuit extortionist to stop.
newsitem.headline: Murderer urges poison biscuit extortionist to stop.

text.p: A convicted double murderer on Tuesday urged an extortionist to stop a bid to free him by threatening to plant poisoned biscuits in Australian supermarkets.
"I want everyone to know that I had no part in these threats," Ron Thomas said in a signed letter issued by his solicitor.

The extortionist threatened to plant biscuits laced with a pesticide in stores in the states of New South Wales and Queensland from Monday unless four police involved in Thomas' case took a lie detector test.
Australia's largest biscuit manufacturer Arnotts, which received the threat, has removed all its products from stores.
"I don't know who made the threats and I have never asked anybody to make them," said Thomas, who is serving two life sentences for a 1991 double shooting murder he says he didn't commit.

"I want to make the strongest possible appeal to whoever has done this not to take these threats any further and to withdraw the threats immediately. I don't want any innocent people harmed in my name."
Police have refused to meet the extortionist's demand.
"Any form of backdown would be wrong because it would only encourage these creatures," Queensland Police Minister Russell Cooper said on Tuesday.
The New South Wales and Queensland state governments on Tuesday offered a combined A$100,000 (US$76,000) reward in the hunt for the extortionist.
Police probing the extortion threat have said they want to question John Bobak, for whom there is already a A$50,000 reward and a warrant in place in relation to the 1991 murders.
Police have warned shoppers to be vigilant, saying other food companies could be targeted.
Arnotts has suspended a few hundred casual workers, but has warned it was prepared to shut down factory lines and suspend up to 1,000 workers.

Arnotts, which is 70 percent controlled by U.S. food giant Campbell Soup Co, says the extortion crisis will cost it A$5.0 million each week in lost sales and is working on tamper-proof packaging to get its products back in stores.
Arnotts sells biscuits to Asia, New Zealand and Pacific island countries, but says its exports are safe and that the company's factories and distribution networks are secure.
Thomas said he thanked the extortionist for trying to help him, but added he preferred if people started a media campaign to free him instead.
"I know you are trying to help me, but this is not the way to do it. Right now I am trying to put together an appeal...If anything is to be done for me it must be done through the courts," he said.
